text: this is a kind of new old Irish Italian
take on mashed potatoes a friend of mine
from Liguria told me about earlier this
year it's mashed potatoes with dandelion
greens very spring and very interesting
it's really Italian it's from Liguria in
fact the northern part of Italy where a
friend of mine and I were sitting and
eating and he just described it to be
and I thought I can't wait to get home
and try this dandelion greens potatoes
olive oil bread crumbs what could be
wrong and it's some Irish because it's
green and because it's potatoes I mean
it's not really Irish but it's a very
nice take on mashed potatoes reminds me
of when I was a kid taking mashed
potatoes and pushing them up with
horrible canned peas only this is taking
mashed potatoes and combining it with
dandelion greens which are bitter and
strong and really powerful food and
delicious food and olive oil which
didn't have when I was a kid really so
take two potatoes not a lot to sizeable
potatoes but you're not going to eat six
potatoes here and boil them peel them
and boil them until they're tender this
task of fishing out all the potatoes is
only happening this way because I'm
going to use the same water to cook the
dandelions a big bunch of dandelions if
the stems are really tough you can get
rid of them these are kind of nice after
into the same water that you cook the
potatoes in should have some salt in
there and one minute to until it until
they're tender then you're going to
drain them maybe rinse them under cold
water to make them easier to handle chop
them up a little bit and finish mashing
them with the potatoes which we can
start on here so figure I'm going to say
a quarter cup of olive oil by which I
mean probably a half a cup I mean if you
used to mashed potatoes with butter and
you've never had mashed potatoes with
olive oil it's already a magnificent
change not that I have anything against
butter but this is really nice we don't
want you don't want whipped potatoes
here you just wanted a nice coarse mesh
one of the things I like about this dish
is this nice combination of potatoes
with
you're using only two potatoes so you're
not it's likely mounds and mounds and
then with them you're getting all the
benefits as it were of these dark leafy
greens which are arguably among the best
foods you can possibly eat but the thing
I really like about this is that it
tastes great so I cook the greens until
they were tender drain them rinse them
under cold water so I could handle them
you could of course just let them sit
for a while squeeze them more or less
dry I don't to be perfectly dry I like
this because it's only two potatoes not
a huge mound of mashed potatoes and it's
combined with this wonderful food
dandelions but mostly it's about that I
like it because it tastes great so it's
fine to try to find so-called healthier
ways to eat but the bottom line has
still got to be that what you're eating
that you want to eat what it is you made
okay now this is going to go you could
serve this this way of course but I'm
putting it in a baking dish ramekin
whatever you want to call it anything
ovenproof will work here these should be
moist the potatoes not as I said not
whipped but kind of chunky the whole
thing shouldn't be wet if it seems too
dry add some more olive oil or some of
the cooking liquid is fine also and then
some bread crumbs on top about a cup and
then we're going to run this under the
broiler for less than two minutes
because when I ran it under the broiler
the other day for two minutes I burned
it so running on little brother for a
minute or two there we go it's pretty
nice
obviously I have nothing against
potatoes but if you're looking for a way
to avoid eating a pound of them at a
time in an interesting new form this is
it
